abstract: Interview with Dr Rudolph Emile Tanzi on his groundbreaking genetic research on Alzheimer's disease and his hopes for new treatment options; photo (M)
snippet: Interview with Dr Rudolph Emile Tanzi on his groundbreaking genetic research on Alzheimer's disease and his hopes for new treatment options; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: On a recent frozen afternoon, Dr. Rudolph Emile Tanzi, a 42-year-old neurogeneticist, was lounging at his beachfront home here near Boston, fingering the new book ''Decoding Darkness: The Search for the Genetic Causes of Alzheimer's Disease,'' which he wrote with Ann B. Parson, a journalist.

abstract: Researchers studying Wadi Ara, Arab village in Israel with unusually high rates of Alzheimer's disease, suspect recessive gene plays role in condition when carried by both parents; all other genes related to Alzheimer's are dominant (S)
snippet: Researchers studying Wadi Ara, Arab village in Israel with unusually high rates of Alzheimer's disease, suspect recessive gene plays role in condition when carried by both parents; all other genes related to Alzheimer's are dominant (S)
lead_paragraph: An Arab village in Israel with unusually high rates of Alzheimer's disease suggests that a recessive gene plays a role in the condition, one that must be carried by both parents to take effect, according to a new study in the journal Neurology.

abstract: Researchers say problems identifying aromas may indicate early Alzheimer's disease, but only when patients do not realize that something is amiss with sense of smell (S)
snippet: Researchers say problems identifying aromas may indicate early Alzheimer's disease, but only when patients do not realize that something is amiss with sense of smell (S)
lead_paragraph: In recent months, researchers have pointed to possible signals of Alzheimer's disease that could allow doctors to detect the ailment before symptoms start. They have spoken of small areas of the brain that appear to shrink, and psychological tests that yield subtle clues.

abstract: Jonathan Kozol Op-Ed article on his father's deterioration from Alzheimer's says Medicare and Medicaid rules should be revised to cover long-term care for this illness; lauds Pres Clinton's plan for $50 million research program to advance early diagnosis and possible prevention of Alzheimer's; photo (M)
snippet: Jonathan Kozol Op-Ed article on his father's deterioration from Alzheimer's says Medicare and Medicaid rules should be revised to cover long-term care for this illness; lauds Pres Clinton's plan for $50 million research program to advance early di...
lead_paragraph: President Clinton recently announced a $50 million research program to advance the early diagnosis and investigate the possible prevention of Alzheimer's, a disease that now afflicts more than four million people in our nation. One of them is my father, and, like others who have seen their parents' mental faculties assaulted by this illness, I was grateful for the president's decision, wishing only that my father were still young enough to benefit.
headline.main: Losing My Father, One Day at a Time
headline.print_headline: Losing My Father, One Day at a Time

abstract: Johnson & Johnson's treatment for Alzheimer's disease, Reminyl, is close to Food and Drug Administration approval (S)
snippet: Johnson & Johnson's treatment for Alzheimer's disease, Reminyl, is close to Food and Drug Administration approval (S)
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson's treatment for Alzheimer's disease, Reminyl, is close to Food and Drug Administration approval, the agency said, bringing the company a step nearer to selling the drug in the United States. Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it had received a so-called approvable letter from the F.D.A. The letters spell out final issues to be resolved before the agency will allow a drug to be marketed; such issues often involve product labeling. A study financed by Johnson & Johnson found that the drug, which has the chemical name of galantamine hydrobromide, improves all three types of disabilities that Alzheimer's patients commonly suffer.

abstract: Gina Kolata column on recent ado over early phase testing of Alzheimer's disease vaccine; discusses ethics of reporting research on drugs that may never make it to market (M)
snippet: Gina Kolata column on recent ado over early phase testing of Alzheimer's disease vaccine; discusses ethics of reporting research on drugs that may never make it to market (M)
lead_paragraph: The news seemed breathtaking. An Alzheimer's vaccine that had previously worked in mice now seemed safe in patients. Many newspapers ran enthusiastic articles; some even put the news on their front pages, signaling that it was among the most important events of the day. Radio and television programs were even more upbeat, hinting strongly that help was on the way for the four million Americans with Alzheimer's.

abstract: As new drugs to treat and even prevent Alzheimer's disease make their way through the pipeline, a basic medical issue has remained unresolved: how can doctors know which patients to medicate if they are not yet showing clear-cut symptoms?    Now researchers believe they may find an answer in the magnetic resonance imaging machines. The findings are reported in a new study paid for by the National Institute on Aging and appearing in this month's issue of the Annals of Neurology.

abstract: Phyllis Finocchio dies at home in Queens, cared for by her family through a long battle with Alzheimer's disease; family opted against tube feeding when she could no longer eat, having learned from support groups that dying people who can no longer eat do not suffer from hunger and thirst and can be kept comfortable with ice chips and swabs to moisten the mouth and lips; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: On a crisp, sunny morning a year ago, in the Queens apartment that had been her home for more than 40 years, death came gently for Phyllis Finocchio. Gazing into her husband's eyes, she squeezed his hand, and then let go of it for the last time.

abstract: Implanting neural cells in the brain shows promise to restore functions lost to stroke, spinal cord injury or neurological diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's; work is spurred by two recent developments, the isolation of stem cells, the primordial cell from which all others evolve, and the discovery that adult brains continue to produce new cells; stem cells can potentially be made into neural cells for transplantation, and in tests with animals these cells have shown the ability to migrate through the brain to where they are needed to repair damage; ethical questions arise with use of embryonic stems cells or neural stem cells derived from fetuses (M)

abstract: LUBAR-Patricia. On May 23, age 76, formerly of Port Washington. Predeceased in 1995 by her beloved husband Robert. Devoted mother of John, Nicholas, Stephen and Andrew. Also survived by five loving grandchildren. Memorial service to be held July 16 at 4:30 PM at the United Methodist Church of Port Washington, 1515 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point. abstract: Brain researchers study memory loss, with view to tracing memory loss in the aging process and developing treatments; studies have shown that more than a third of elderly can remember names and events in their lives as sharply as their 20-year-old counterparts, suggesting that memory loss is not necessarily inevitable; quiz shows guidelines for differentiating between age-related memory loss, and early Alzheimer's; photos (M)
snippet: Brain researchers study memory loss, with view to tracing memory loss in the aging process and developing treatments; studies have shown that more than a third of elderly can remember names and events in their lives as sharply as their 20-year-old...
lead_paragraph: Ruth Arnold can recall a time when her memory was perfect. Years ago, working as a college reference librarian, she could put her finger on any piece of minutia at will. ''I remembered all the books and what was in them,'' Mrs. Arnold said.
headline.main: Is Memory Loss Inevitable? Maybe Not
headline.print_headline: Is Memory Loss Inevitable? Maybe Not

abstract: SPIVACK-John D. 80, passed away December 23, 1999, in Suffern, NY, after a long struggle with Alzheimer's disease. He received his Ph.D. in chemistry from McGill in 1947, married, emigrated to the United States, and became a loving father to three children. He worked for thirty-six years for Ciba Geigy Corporation in Ardsley, NY, on light stabilizers and antioxidants and was considered an international expert in the field, credited with over 125 patents. He was politically active throughout his life, and culturally involved in Yiddish language and cultural activities. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Thelma Goresky Spivack of Chestnut Ridge, NY; two sisters, Ruth Rubin and Esther Marks; three children, Berel, Ellen and Simon; as well as three grandchildren, Daniel, Jordan and Jacqueline. Private services were held at the family home. Donations to the Alzheimer's and Parkinson's foundations are appreciated.

abstract: Dr Muriel Gillick, writing in New England Journal of Medicine, says nursing homes and hospitals should end the widespread use of stomach tubes to feed people with advanced Alzheimer's disease or other types of dementia; says that there is no evidence they help most patients and that they can be harmful; says patients would be better off being helped to eat or being fed by mouth and that terminally ill and lucid people who stop eating and drinking do not have to suffer hunger or thirst before they die, as many families fear when they agree to use of feeding tubes; same view was expressed in recent article in Journal of American Medical Assn and is shared by Alzheimer's Assn (M)
snippet: Dr Muriel Gillick, writing in New England Journal of Medicine, says nursing homes and hospitals should end the widespread use of stomach tubes to feed people with advanced Alzheimer's disease or other types of dementia; says that there is no evide...
lead_paragraph: Nursing homes and hospitals should end the widespread use of stomach tubes to feed people with advanced Alzheimer's disease or other types of dementia, according to an article published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

abstract: Bone marrow cells that would normally turn into tendon, cartilage, bone, muscle and fat can also turn into nerve cells, scientists report. All that is needed is to add a simple mixture of chemicals to a broth that nourishes the marrow cells in the laboratory. While cautioning that the work is in its earliest stages, researchers say it may eventually offer a new source of nerve cells to treat spinal cord injuries or diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's.   Gina Kolata
lead_paragraph: Bone marrow cells that would normally turn into tendon, cartilage, bone, muscle and fat can also turn into nerve cells, scientists report. All that is needed is to add a simple mixture of chemicals to a broth that nourishes the marrow cells in the laboratory. While cautioning that the work is in its earliest stages, researchers say it may eventually offer a new source of nerve cells to treat spinal cord injuries or diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Gina Kolata
headline.main: August 13-19; New Hope for Nerve Disease
headline.print_headline: August 13-19; New Hope for Nerve Disease

abstract: When people with advanced Alzheimer's disease become unable to eat, it might seem humane and logical to feed them through a stomach tube, as many hospitals and nursing homes do. But tube feeding is far from an act of kindness, according to an article in The New England Journal of Medicine. Experts say tube feeding does not help most demented patients, and may increase their suffering: they often pull out the tubes, and wind up in restraints and sedated.     DENISE GRADY
lead_paragraph: When people with advanced Alzheimer's disease become unable to eat, it might seem humane and logical to feed them through a stomach tube, as many hospitals and nursing homes do. But tube feeding is far from an act of kindness, according to an article in The New England Journal of Medicine. Experts say tube feeding does not help most demented patients, and may increase their suffering: they often pull out the tubes, and wind up in restraints and sedated.
headline.main: January 16-22; Feeding Tubes Can Be Cruel
headline.print_headline: January 16-22; Feeding Tubes Can Be Cruel

abstract: Nation's largest chain of assisted living facilities, operated by Alterra Healthcare Corp, comes under scrutiny by state regulators over quality of care and safety conditions at some of its centers; regulators in at least five states complain that Alterra facilities have untrained staffs, fail to give elderly residents needed drugs and nutritional supplements, or fail to protect their safety; Alterra executives say state reports reflect isolated instances, and that company's weakened financial condition is not affecting daily operations; regulators have found problems at assisted living centers run by other providers, and many Alterra residences receive high marks from regulators and advocates for patients; but Alterra's problems may be emblematic of broader industry issue--how financial strains, managerial turmoil and labor problems can upset operations of even those assisted living companies with good reputations; photos; graph (L)
snippet: Nation's largest chain of assisted living facilities, operated by Alterra Healthcare Corp, comes under scrutiny by state regulators over quality of care and safety conditions at some of its centers; regulators in at least five states complain that...
lead_paragraph: The nation's largest chain of assisted living facilities, including about 150 residences for people with Alzheimer's disease, has come under scrutiny in recent months by state regulators over the quality of care and safety conditions at some of its centers.

abstract: New Hampshire affiliate of National Right to Life committee, which opposes Sen John McCain's presidential candidacy because he wants to change campaign finance laws, picks up on joking remark McCain made, accusing him of being insensitive to elderly (S)
snippet: New Hampshire affiliate of National Right to Life committee, which opposes Sen John McCain's presidential candidacy because he wants to change campaign finance laws, picks up on joking remark McCain made, accusing him of being insensitive to elder...
lead_paragraph: One day last September, Senator John McCain was bantering with reporters on his campaign bus about something that had slipped his mind, and he joked that at 63 he was becoming old and senile. ''The nice thing about Alzheimer's,'' he cracked, ''is you get to hide your own Easter eggs.''

abstract: JOSEPH-Maxine Stern. Age 81, passed away February 4, 2000 after a brief illness. She was the Medical Director for the Methadone program for the New York State Narcotics Addiction Control Commission. She was the beloved wife of the late S. Seymour Joseph, M.D. Loving mother and motherin-law to Marilyn Joseph and Warren Regelmann, cherished grandmother of Adam Gustave Regelmann and David Joseph Regelmann. Devoted sister to the late Frederic Stern, also survived by dear sister-in-law Diane Stern. Memorial services will be held in St. Paul, MN. Contributions are preferred to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association in memory of her late husband.

abstract: DWYER-Albert Hayden. Of Demarest, NJ, former general counsel and vice president of the Children's Television Workshop and a CBS attorney for nearly two decades, died on August 8, 2000 at the age of 79. He was the beloved husband of Laura Campbell Dwyer, father of Albert H. Dwyer, Jr. of Houston, TX., and William C. Dwyer of Santa Cruz, CA, and grandfather of four. A memorial service will be held at 3:00 P.M., August 19 at the Church of the Atonement, Engle Street at Highwood Avenue, Tenafly, NJ. Step-father of Susan DeVoge and Deborah Dunn. Adored grandfather of 12. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 68 PM, and Wednesday, 12-3 PM. abstract: HOFFMAN-Leon. On September 30, 2000, at 85 years old. Beloved husbnd of the late Rita. Loving father of Roy and his wife Sandra, Jane and her husband Dr. David Zelman. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Mark, Lori, Jeremy and Allison. Dear brother of Rose Hateau. Unselfishly placing his family's needs above his own, he was an exemplary role model for his adoring grandchildren. Former New York Daily Mirror photographer, former President of the New York Press Photographers Association and member of the Board of Directors for over 40 years. Services Tuesday, October 3, 10 AM, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, LI. Contribuitons in his name to Alzheimer's Association.

abstract: BERARD-Frederica Stevens, died May 12, 2000 at age 92, in Middletown, R.I. Daughter of the late Frederic William Stevens and Alice Caroline Seely Stevens. Predeceased by her beloved husband Philippe Roger Berard and her daughter Joan Hone King. Survived by her daughter Frederica Stevens Neff and Eugenie Gallatin Angles, her son Philip Hone Auerbach, twelve grandchildren and twelve great - grandchildren. Funeral to be held at the American Cathedral in Paris on June 9, 2000 at 2:30PM. Donations may be made in her memory to Columbia University Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, 230 West 168th Street, New York, NY 10032.

abstract: KETIVE-Shirley ''Shirl.'' Of Fort Lauderdale, FL, on October 20. Adoring, devoted wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Alice (Fred) Rudin, Harriet Lerner and Sam (Randy) Ketive. Revered grandmother of Mitchell and Robert Rudin, and Rebecca Rudin Schoenberg, Valerie Ann and Jacques Lerner, and Kimberly Ketive. Great-grandmother of Scott and Benjamin Rudin, Elisabeth and Katherine Lerner, Greg, Jacob and Lilly Rudin, Miles and Paul Schoenberg. We pray she gets a chance to be with her beloved ''Nicky'' again. Interment private. Visits may be paid to the home of Randy and Samuel Ketive, Monday evening through Wednesday, October 25. abstract: POLLACK-Irving. Died at 86 of Alzheimer's on July 5, exactly 32 years after his beloved wife Marcella. Devoted father of Darryle, Carla and Josh; loving grandfather of Rachel, Leah, Aaron, Alli, Nicholas, Daniel and Spencer. He was an important pioneer and visionary who helped develop Miami Beach into a thriving tourist area. Between the late 40's and early 80's he owned and operated hotels including the Surfcomber, Nautilus, Shelborne, and Newport. He grew up in Monticello, graduated from Cornell in 1935 and moved to Miami Beach after the war. Known as a successful businessman, he was totally dedicated to his family, who will always love and miss him.
lead_paragraph: POLLACK-Irving. Died at 86 of Alzheimer's on July 5, exactly 32 years after his beloved wife Marcella. Devoted father of Darryle, Carla and Josh; loving grandfather of Rachel, Leah, Aaron, Alli, Nicholas, Daniel and Spencer. He was an important pioneer and visionary who helped develop Miami Beach into a thriving tourist area. Between the late 40's and early 80's he owned and operated hotels including the Surfcomber, Nautilus, Shelborne, and Newport. He grew up in Monticello, graduated from Cornell in 1935 and moved to Miami Beach after the war. Known as a successful businessman, he was totally dedicated to his family, who will always love and miss him.

abstract: RICHMAN-Lillian B. On December 25, 2000 at age 76. Beloved wife of the late Dr. George Richman. Cherished and devoted mother of David. Adoring grandmother of Shoshanna Richman and Gabriel Richman. Beloved & adored sister of May Glantz and the late Saul Sorrin and adoring mother-in-law of Elizabeth Sultan. Lillian was a former partner at Bower & Gardner, and one of the first female partners at a major law firm in New York. She set a standard of excellence both in her profession and in her life that touched everyone. The funeral will take place at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York on Wednesday, December 27th, 2000, at 1 P.M. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Lillian's name to the Alzheimer's Association.

abstract: SHELAN-Harold Sidney. On June 3, 2000, at the age of 85. Beloved husband of the late Lucille (nee Geist). Loving father of Diane and Steven Fox. Cherished grandfather of Jayson. Loving brother of Bernard and Bobby. Uncle of Jane, Harris, Michael and Scott Maslansky. Mr. Shelan attained rank of Major in the United States Army Air Corps 366th Fighter Division during World War II. Visiting hours Monday, June 5, 7-9 PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. Funeral service Tuesday, June 6, 9:30 AM, at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. Contributions in Mr. Shelan's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

abstract: SCHMELTZER-Eleanor, 86, died Wednesday in Rye Brook, NY. Born in Greenwich, CT on April 22, 1913 she was the daughter of the late Alexander and Clara S. Hall Dommerich and the wife of the late Robert Schmeltzer. She attended Greenwich Academy, Rosemary Hall and Mrs. Hall's School in Pittsfield, MA. She was a member of the National Horse show, the Junior League of New York, Affiliate with Squadron A., Field Club of Sarasota, FL and the East Chop Beach Club in Martha's Vineyard, a parishoner of West Tisbury Congregational Church in Martha's Vineyard. Services will be held Monday March 6, at 11:30 AM in Dingletown Community Church, Stanwich Road, Greenwich. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 607 Main Ave., Norwalk, CT or to a charity of one's choice.

abstract: HEILICER-Bernard, 79, of Plainview died July 2, 2000, of natural causes after a short illenss. He enjoyed a successful career as an aeronautical engineer at Fairchild Republic. His loving and cherished wife of 57 years, Norma, passed on in September, 1999. Cherished father of Sandra Barmak, Lorraine Glaser and Shelley Gross. Loved father-in-law of Len Barmak, Gary Glaser and Michael Gross. Loving and adoring grandfather (''Pop'') of Allan and Julie Barmak and Lesley and Michael Reilly, Samantha and Evan Glaser, and Jeffrey and Amy Gross; loving and adoring great-grandfather of Taylor Barmak. Services on Thursday, July 6, 12 noon at Guttermans Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury. Donations may be sent to the Alzheimers Association or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center. He will be greatly missed.

abstract: SCHWARTZ-Sam passed away at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City on August 30, 2000 after a prolonged illness. Loving father of Sheila Paulos and grandfather to Leah Paulos and Daniel Paulos, father-in-law of John Allen Paulos. Beloved companion of Marsha Engelsher. Jean Gibenstein his wife of 56 years died of Alzheimer's Disease in 1997. Born in New York City in 1917, Mr. Schwartz was founder and president of Metropolitan Window Washing Company in White Plains, NY. He lived life passionately with great love for his family and friends. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services will be held at Louis Hirsch and Sons, Inc., 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, New York on Thursday, August 31st at 1:30 P.M. Interment is at Cedar Park, Paramus, New Jersey.

abstract: BAGNALL-June. Died November 28, 2000 at age 74. Ms. Bagnall was the daughter of the late Jeanette and Richard Bagnall. She is survived by her nephew Rodney Stewart, his wife Anita, son Jonathan and her many friends and neighbors. Ms. Bagnall was a New York City art teacher for over 30 years. She received her MFA from Columbia University. We remember her for her many good works including working with Alzheimers patients, the 23rd Precinct Community Council and St. Ambrose Church. There will be a viewing on Friday, December 1, 910AM with a service following at St. Ambrose Church, 9 W. 130 St, NYC. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers, donations be given to the National Kidney Foundation of NY/NJ, 1250 Broadway, Suite 2001, New York, New York 10001.

She received her MFA from Columbia University. We remember her for her many good works including working with Alzheimers patients, the 23rd Precinct Community Council and St. Ambrose Church. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers, donations be given to the National Kidney Foundation of NY/NJ, 1250 Broadway, Suite 2001, New York, New York 10001.

abstract: KARSON-Nelson. Of Great Neck died on April 16, 2000. He was 79 years old and died at North Shore University Hospital of complications following a stroke. Mr. Karson was a retired electrical engineer. He moved to Great Neck in 1957 and resided there until his death. He was married to the late Janet Rothschild Karson, who died in 1995. Mr. Karson is survived by a son, Scott and his wife Joleen of Stony Brook; a daughter, Shelley and her partner Harriet Mendlowitz of Jackson Heights; a granddaughter, Tobi Karson Sevdalakis and her husband Christos; a grandson Jared Karson; and a sister Annette Karson. A memorial service for Mr. Karson was held at the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island in Garden City on April 22, 2000. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 66 South St., Patchogue, NY 11772 or to Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic, 70 Maple Ave., Smithtown, New York 11787.

abstract: HALPRIN-Maxine (nee Rickard), age 72, of Hoboken, NJ, formerly of Juno Beach and Miami, San Antonio and New York City, died May 27, 2000. Daughter of the late George ''Tex'' Rickard, the boxing promoter and founder of the New York Rangers Hockey Club, who built the Madison Square Garden building that stood at Eighth Ave. and 50th St. in NYC. Devoted mother of Edwin Rickard Goodfellow of San Antonio, TX, Joan Christine Halprin of Beaufort, SC and Joseph Rickard Halprin of Hoboken, NJ. Her smile, friendship and love will be missed by all. Visitation on Tuesday from 7-9PM at Lawton-Turso Funeral Home, 631 Washington St., Hoboken. Funeral Wednesday. Mass 10AM at Sts. Peter and Paul R.C. Church, 4th and Hudson Sts. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association or American Heart Association greatly appreciated.

abstract: JENNINGS-Fred M. Of Hobe Sound, FL, and Sandwich, NH, formerly of New Canaan, CT, on November 4, 2000, in Augusta, ME. He received his BA degree at San Diego State College and law degree at the University of Chicago. Fred served in the Pacific during WWII as an officer on the USS Guardfish, the only submarine to be awarded the Presidential Unit Citation for Valor twice. He worked in New York City in the legal profession at Milbank Tweed law firm and as House Counsel at Riegel Paper Corp. and VP at Great Lakes Paper Company in White Plains, NY. He started an American style feedlot in Australia in 1974. He is survived by his beloved wife, Peggy, his son, Douglas of Hallowell, ME, daughter, Nanci Ouellette of Lansing, MI, and two grandchildren, Amy and Douglas Jennings. Services will be for the family in Hallowell, ME. Memorial contributions to the Alzheimers Association, Chicago, IL.

He worked in New York City in the legal profession at Milbank Tweed law firm and as House Counsel at Riegel Paper Corp. and VP at Great Lakes Paper Company in White Plains, NY. He started an American style feedlot in Australia in 1974. abstract: HOPPENFELD RESIKA - Elsa. March 2, 2000. Adored mother of Carol and husband Howard Hillman, loving grandmother to Molly Mehlsack, beloved aunt of Barbara Mehlsack, Herbert and Jeannette Spiegel, Beaty Evin, Lili Spiegel, Sol Spiegel, Shirley Sklar, Diana Katz, and many loving Hoppenfeld nieces and nephews, and Finn and Barbara Caspersen, Finn Michael and Emily, Eric and Anna, Sam, and Andrew Caspersen, and Nancy Manheim. She loved humanity and worked for social justice all of her life. Her family and friends were the most important thing in the world to her. She showed us her love and support in every waking moment. We will miss her, but we will carry on her legacy. Service Sunday, March 5, 3PM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cencer Center or the Guttman Institute.

abstract: MURPHY-Edmond C. Age 79, of Baldwin, NY, died Friday, January 7. Beloved husband of the late Blanche Murphy and devoted father of three children and seven grandchildren. Dear brother of Patricia and Richard. Distinguished career as Chief Clerk of Family Court for City of New York. Highly respected college basketball official and former President of the American Association of Basketball Officials. An avid golfer, he will be remembered for sharp wit, compassion for others and devotion to his family. Friends may visit at Vanella's Funeral Chapel, 2860 Long Beach Rd., Oceanside, NY, on Sunday, January 9, 2-5 PM, and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, January 10, at St. Christopher's, Merrick Rd, Baldwin, NY, at 10:30 AM. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Ave., Suite 1000, Chicago, IL 60611-1676.

abstract: YOUNG-Lucile Halle. A native of Cleveland, Ohio; died at the age of 89 on September 1, 2000 after a long illness. She attended Miss Fuller's School in Ossining, NY. She was married to the late Fritz Wolff and the late Lewis B. Young of Drexel, Burnham, Lambert & Co. She began her career in the children's wear department at Jane Engels. Afterwards she started the Infant and Children's Department at Henri Bendel. Lucile was recognized as one of the industry's leading buyers of fine children's clothes until she retired in 1962. She is survived by her daughter Susan W. Spiegel and her husband Andrew of Highland Park, Illinois; and stepdaughter Linda Barnes. Adored grandmother of Sally Spiegel and Jill Spiegel Brozic and her husband Joe of Minneapolis. Stepgrandmother of Andrew and Kimberly and her husband Al and great-stepgrandmother of David Alexander. Friends will be received at 1075 Park Avenue from 6-9PM on Thursday September 14. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimers Foundation.

abstract: BADER-Nathan. On May 12, 2000 at age 92. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Adored father of Ann Bader Geller. Loving grandfather of Richard, Larry and Tracy and great grandfather of Alixandre, Zachary and Sophia. Graveside service at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Sunday, May 14, 2:00 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation or the American Heart Association.     BADER-Nathan. Papa. The kindest, warmest, most wonderful grandfather that we could ever have. Nobody could ever match you. Love, Richard and Tracy     BADER-Nathan. I will love you and miss you forever. May flights of angels sing thee to thy rest All my Love, Ann     BADER-Nathan. To my beloved Dear. Thank you for a wonderful marriage of almost 70 years. Beatrice     BADER-Nathan. Our condolences to the family of Nathan Bader. Rev. and Mrs. C.A.F.T. Spray Coral Spray and Andy Spray     BADER-Nathan. Grandpa. You are the best. I will love you always. Tracy

abstract: LORBER-Ruth, 83. Of Lake Worth FL, passed away on December 19, 2000. Mrs. Lorber and her husband Jerry owned and directed Camp Ranger for over 30 years. She was a Life Member of Hadassah, an Officer of the Sisterhood at the Israel Center of Hillcrest Manor and an active fundraiser for the Friends of the Retarded. She leaves to cherish her memory, a devoted family: loving husband of 62 years, Dr. Jerome W. Lorber; beloved children Susan and Matthew Liebman and Sandy and Sheldon Cohen; loving brothers and sister Irving, Charlotte and Harold. A very special Grandma to Eileen and Lowell, Alan and Sandi, David and Alison, and Debbie. Great-grandmother to Kyle and Jake, and many nieces and nephews. She will be greatly missed by her family and many dear friends who knew and loved her. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Ruth Lorber's memory to the Alzheimers Association. Shiva will be held on Monday evening at 8 PM and all day and evening on Tuesday at the home of Susan Liebman, 101-06 67th Drive, Apartment 5A in Forest Hills.

abstract: BURGHEIMER-Alan Joseph. A Rye resident, died on November 24, 2000, at his home, at age 87. Born in NYC on July 16, 1913, he is the son of the late Jacob and Gertrude Kahn Burgheimer. A veteran of the United States Navy, he served the nation during WWII. Mr. Burgheimer was the owner and executive of the Fisher Beer Co. in NYC. On June 20, 1939, he married Jeanne Schwarz at the Waldorf Astoria. He was a member of the City Athletic Club in Manhattan, as well as the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck. In addition to his wife Jeanne, of Rye, he is survived by his daughters Margo Burgheimer of Rye, and Joanne Robinson and her husband Jerrold of Keswick, VA. He is predeceased by a sister, Sylvia Kapp. Funeral service will be held on Monday, 11:30 AM, at Zion Memorial, followed by entombment at Maimonides Cemetery in Elmont, NY. The family requests that donations be sent to the Alzheimer's Association in his memory. For information contact Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY 10543; 914-381-1809. www.zionmemorialchapel.com

abstract: SALLEE-Suzanne D. 92 years old, Lake Worth, FL died Monday, September 25 at her residence. Born in New York City, former resident of Cold Spring Harbor, NY graduated from Rosemary Hall, and attended Bennett Jr. College where she later served on the Board of Trustees. Mrs. Sallee and her husband, George, retired to Key Biscayne, FL in 1967. He died in 1985 shortly after their 50th wedding anniversary. Mrs. Sallee moved to West Palm Beach, FL in 1989. She is survived by her son, John C. Sallee of Manila, the Phillippines; her daughter, Mrs. Clifford Slater of Pacific Palisades, CA; and her five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 3, at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the Sea, Palm Beach, FL. Graveside service Thursday at the Memorial Cemetery of St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Alzheimer's Association, Greater Palm Beach Area Chapter, Inc., 1325 S. Congress Ave., Suite 203, Boynton Beach, FL 33426.

abstract: HAUSER-LEVIN-Lillian. 92, of Great Neck, NY. Died peacefully at home on March 25, 2000. She was predeceased by her first husband, the late Milton I. Hauser, and by her second husband, the late Jess Levin. She is survived by her children Harry and Deborah Hauser of Newton, MA, and Richard and Joan Hauser of Northport, NY, and by her grandchildren: Mark and Andrea Hauser of Newton, MA, and their sons Jeffrey and George; Joshua and Kimberly Hauser of Vancouver, BC, and their sons Zachary and Jacob; Bradford and Nurit Hauser of Jerusalem, Israel, and their children Daniel, Yohanatan, Tuvya and Rachel; Matthew Hauser and Susan Motamed of Brooklyn, NY, and their sons Benjamin and Alexander; Jonathan and Quinella Hauser of Jonesboro, GA, and their son Jonathan II; Betsy and Douglas Abernathy of Naperville, IL, and their daughters Celia, Rose and Jane; and by Andrew Hauser of San Diego, CA. abstract: ENGEL-Joseph G. Of Princeton, New Jersey. Died peacefully on May 7, 2000 at age 83 after a long illness. Survived by his wife of 52 years, Jane D. Engel of Princeton, NJ. Also survived by his sons, William V. Engel of Basking Ridge, NJ, Richard F. Engel of West Windsor, NJ, and Robert J. Engel of Wayland, MA, his daughters-inlaw, Brenda F. Engel and Patricia H. Engel, his five grandchildren, John, Robert, Bill, Betsy, and Libby, his brother Edward G. Engel and his sister, Mary E. Flannery. Funeral services and interment private. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, May 21, 2000 at 1:30 P.M. at The Pingry School, Martinsville Road, Bernards Township, NJ. abstract: JOHNSTON-Robert Emmett, 83, died 1-15-00 in Florida after a long illness. Mr. Johnston, formerly of New York, was retired president and chief executive officer of Harbor Distributing Corp. in Hicksville. Harbor distributed Anheuser Busch beers. Previously, he was president of Port Distributing Corp. of Long Island City. Mr. Johnston served in the Army in Europe with the 3rd Infantry Division from 1944 through January 1946. He was graduate of Pace University. In 1981 he was honored by the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, and in 1983 by the New York Kidney Foundation. He was predeceased by his wife, Patricia, (nee McCabe), in 1995. He is survived by three daughters, Patricia O'Hearne of New Hampshire, Stefanie Gugelot and Mary Morrell of Florida; five grandchildren, Brian O'Hearne, Mary O'Hearne, Jennifer Shepard, Deirdre Gugelot, and Caitlin Morrell; five great-grandchildren; devoted friends, Felicita Gimenez and Gus Camarasa; and many nieces and nephews. Visitation at the Branch Funeral Home Inc., 190 E. Main St., Smithtown will be on Wednesday from 3-5 and 79pm. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Alzheimer's Association of Massachusetts, 36 Cameron Ave., Cambridge, MA 02140

abstract: Elan Corp acquires Dura Pharmaceuticals Inc for $1.8 billion in stock; graph (S)
snippet: Elan Corp acquires Dura Pharmaceuticals Inc for $1.8 billion in stock; graph (S)
lead_paragraph: The Dublinbased drugmaker the Elan Corporation acquired Dura Pharmaceuticals, Inc. of San Diego, for $1.8 billion in stock, paying 0.6715 of an Elan A.D.R. for each Dura share. The purchase, Elan's third acquisition this year, raises its North American sales force to more than 1,000. Dura's antibiotics and its Spiros brand of inhaler had sales of $301 million in 1999. The products will broaden Elan's offerings, which are now focused on painkillers and treatments for breast cancer and Alzheimer's disease. Brian Lavery

abstract: GREENE-Wallace B.. Formerly of Newburgh, NY, died peacefully at age 88 on January 13 in Goshen, NY. After graduating from New York University in 1934, he founded the accounting firm of Robbins Greene and Sosnoff with offices in Newburgh and New York City (which firm subsequently merged into Citrin Cooperman and Company) and became active in the American Institute of CPAs and served as President of the MidHudson Chapter of the New York State Society of CPAs as well as Chairman of the Ethics Committee. Despite the demands of his accounting profession, he made a significant commitment to public service, serving as a member of the Board of Directors and as the President of St. Luke's Hospital in Newburgh, President of the Newburgh Lions Club and President of the Otterkill Country Club. He still managed to find time for his passion for photography, classical music and bass fishing in the St. Lawrence River. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, his son, Stephen, his daughter-in-law, Marilyn, his granddaughters, Lisa Mirsky and Jennifer Susser, and his greatgrandsons, Jack David Mirsky and Michael Drew Mirsky, all of whom he cherished and all of whom will miss him dearly. He was truly a class act. In lieu of flowers, donations in Wallace's name can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., NYC 10017.

abstract: GELMAN-Milton. Age 90, of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died Thursday after a brief illness. He leaves his loving family, his wife Sylvia (Garfield) of West Palm Beach, two daughters, Arlene Brod and her companion Barry Kay of Great Neck, NY, and Nancy Blecher Davis and her husband Franklin Davis of Brookline, MA, three grandchildren, Mark Blecher and wife Robin Skirboll of San Francisco, Mari Blecher and husband Rick Tetzeli of Brooklyn and Craig Blecher and wife Angela of Richmond, VA, and three great-grandchildren, Robert and Kerry Blecher and Jonah Tetzeli. Milton Gelman practiced law in New York for 40 years and was a significant leader in the Jewish community of Brooklyn. A former President of Progressive Synagogue, Mr. Gelman received numerous honors and awards and was recognized by the State of Israel for his work on behalf of Israel Bonds. He was looked to for advice by several generations of friends and relatives who were fortunate enough to know this truly giving man. A graveside service will take place 1 PM, Sunday, November 5 at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY. Donations may be sent to the Alzheimers Association or charity of choice. For information, contact ''Gutterman's,'' Brooklyn, NY.

abstract: GORDON-Lawrence. Born July 26, 1922, died September 8, 2000, of New York and Palm Beach, following a courageous battle with Alzheimer's and cancer. He was the devoted son of the late Harry and Etta Gordon and brother to Seymour. Lawrence is survived by his loving wife Janet and their children, Wendy, Scott, Peter and Petula, and from a previous marriage, daughter Kathy and grandson Eric. A decorated World War II veteran and a pioneer of industry, he was Chairman of the Board and CEO of Lehigh Valley Industries and Blue Ridge Winkler Textiles, among other Fortune 500 companies. Lawrence was a loving, charismatic, brilliant, dynamic, creative and adventurous man, and a champion golfer. Our lives have been blessed by his honor, integrity and love. He was a loving husband, father, colleague and friend, and he will be deeply missed by all who have known him. As Lord Tennyson wrote: ''Love is the only gold.'' Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street, Monday, September 11, 5 PM. A celebration of his life will follow the service. Contributions can be made to: Foundation of Neurologic Diseases, 10 State Street, Newburyport, MA 01950, Attn: Dr. Selkoe or to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Health Care System, First Avenue at 16th St, NY, NY 10003-9973.

abstract: MACKIN-John F. 85. Died on August 25, 2000. Formerly of Throgs Neck, Scarsdale and Long Beach Island, New Jersey. He was born on February 3, 1915 to John and Catherine (nee Smith) Mackin in NYC. John was a U.S. Army veteran during W.W.II. Mr. Mackin was a basketball official and baseball umpire at high school and college levels and a member of Catholic High School Athletic Association Hall of Fame. John worked for Metropolitan Life for 44 years, retiring in 1979. He is predeceased by his wife Edith (nee Connelly) Mackin in 1976, three sisters and one brother. He is survived by one son, Joseph Mackin of Hawthorne, NY; three daughters, Peg Adamo of Chappaqua, NY, Mary Grosso of Hingham, MA, Patricia Walsh of Wilton, CT; one brother, Peter Mackin of Yonkers, NY and twelve grandchildren. Reposing, Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave, Hawthorne, NY, (914) 769-4404, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, Holy Rosary Church, Hawthorne, NY on Monday, 11:00 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimer's Association Westchester Chapter, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605, would be appreciated.

abstract: BADER-Nathan. On May 12, 2000 at age 92. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Adored father of Ann Bader Geller. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation or the American Heart Association.     BADER - Nathan. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Nathan Bader. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary     BADER-Nathan. Papa. The kindest, warmest, most wonderful grandfather that we could ever have. Nobody could ever match you. Love, Richard and Tracy     BADER-Nathan. I will love you and miss you forever. May flights of angels sing thee to thy rest All my Love, Ann     BADER-Nathan. To my beloved Dear. Thank you for a wonderful marriage of almost 70 years. Beatrice     BADER-Nathan. Our condolences to the family of Nathan Bader. Rev. and Mrs. C.A.F.T. Spray Coral Spray and Andy Spray     BADER-Nathan. Grandpa. You are the best. I will love you always. Tracy

abstract: BETTMANN-Robert E. (Born December 22, 1922-December 24, 00) Bob, ''Mr B.'', a longtime resident of Hartsdale and Edgemont, New York. Devoted husband to Lynn. Loving father of Ellen Piontek of Holliston, MA, and Andy Poland of Milford, Connecticut. Graduate of Columbia Grammar School, attended University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, until joining the army during W.W. II. Was a P.O.W. Worked in the textile business. Volunteered 1000's of hours to the Dad's Club, Boy Scouts, Kiwanas and others. Received numerous awards including Silver Beaver Award and President's Citation for volunteerism. Devoted cousin and friend to so many. Also leaves grandchildren Kelly, Mike, Kenny, Cliff, Tim and Todd. Will be deeply missed in his community and by all those whose life he has touched. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Bob Fund c/o Ellen Piontek, 170 Mellen Street, Holliston, MA. 01746. Or to the Alzheimer's foundation or American Cancer Society or The Connecticut Hospice, Bradford, Ct. Visiting hours at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY, 914725-1137, Thursday December 28, 8:30AM-10:30AM. abstract: CARR-Dorothy Healey, born on July 17, 1917, loving wife of Peter, & mother of Kevin, Brian, Michael, Kelly Anne & Colin, passed away peacefully June 25, 2000 at the San Diego Hospice. Dorothy suffered with CHF, COPD, HTN, Dementia of Alzheimer's Type. Following a family service at the Church of Nativity, Rancho Santa Fe, CA, her ashes were scattered at sea. After graduating Cum Laude from Trinity College, Washington D.C., Dorothy served in the last class of The Women's Auxiliary Service Pilots (WASPS) in World War II. Dorothy & Peter Carr were married January 23, 1954 at St. Patrick's Cathedral, NY where they resided until they moved to Greenwich, CT. in 1957. In 1983, the Carrs moved to Rancho Santa Fe, CA. In addition to her husband, Peter, Dorothy is survived by four of their five children. Michael passed away in 1995. Kevin, wife Randa & daughter Caroline reside in Simsbury, CT. Brian, his wife Nancy & their children Ryan, Victoria & Daniel are living in Cos Cob, CT. Kelly Anne, husband Neil Winterbottom & two girls, Caitlin & Jennifer live in San Mateo, CA. Colin currently resides in Terrebonne, OR. Those wishing to honor the memory of Dorothy Carr may make donations to the San Diego Hospice, 4311 Third Avenue, San Diego, CA. 92103.

abstract: Article on unknown role of genetics in determining how long person will live; questions whether regimen of exercise and healthy eating will prolong life or prevent disease that person is genetically predisposed to get; notes difficulty of compiling statistics on the subject; drawing (M)
snippet: Article on unknown role of genetics in determining how long person will live; questions whether regimen of exercise and healthy eating will prolong life or prevent disease that person is genetically predisposed to get; notes difficulty of compilin...
lead_paragraph: MY father is not an optimistic person, but he certainly had a rosy view of the life expectancies in his family. Everyone, he always said, lived into their late 80's or even their late 90's, and died, not of a specific disease, but of ''old age.'' My mother said her family was equally long- lived. Naturally, my sisters and I grew up thinking that we were genetically blessed.

abstract: Divison of Hyatt hotel company, in partnership with Forest City Daly developers, opens Classic Residence by Hyatt, new high-rise for seniors, in Yonkers, NY (S)
snippet: Divison of Hyatt hotel company, in partnership with Forest City Daly developers, opens Classic Residence by Hyatt, new high-rise for seniors, in Yonkers, NY (S)
lead_paragraph: The first residents are moving into a new high-rise for seniors built in Yonkers by a division of the Hyatt hotel company in partnership with Forest City Daly developers. The 17-story building has 310 apartments, with mostly independent living units, a personal care section and an area for Alzheimer's sufferers.

abstract: POWERS-Ruth Pedersen. Died July 25, 2000 in Saint Louis, MO. at the age of 93. She had a long, effective career as a social worker in Buffalo with the Family Service, and in New York City at Travelers' Aid & Community Service Society. Ms. Powers was born in Brooklyn and moved to Stroudsburg, PA. during her high school years. She graduated from Cornell University, with a B.A. and from the New York School of Social Work with a MSW. At Travelers' Aid, she was in charge of the Port Department in the years after WWII, assisting the displaced persons arriving at the New York docks. She then worked at Community Service Society where she managed the Homemaker Service Program that offered temporary support to help clients weather a variety of domestic crises. After her retirement from CSS, she lived an active, independent life in Morningside Gardens where she enjoyed serving as surrogate grandma to several foreign students. For the past three years, she suffered from Alzheimer's Disease, finally succumbing, reluctantly to its complications. She was briefly married to Wollerton Powers and had two daughters, Elizabeth Harris of New York & Susan Lagunoff of Saint Louis, MO. She has five grandchildren, Nick and Sam Jordan, and Rachel, Liza and Michael Lagunoff, and one great granddaughter Sasha Lagunoff Eberhardt. An older sister, Laura Henninger lives in Seattle. Memorial contributions may be made to Habitat for Humanity, 334 Furman Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

abstract: REA-Elizabeth (Betty). Former Broadway actress, retired daytime TV casting director and social activist died December 23, 1999 of respiratory failure in Santa Monica, CA, she was 82. She was born Elizabeth Wilson in Montreal to Morris Wilson, President of the Royal Bank of Canada, Chanellor of McGill University and Clara Leone Wilson. In New York while appearing on Broadway in ''Media'' she met her future husband Oliver Rea who helped found The Gutherie Theater. Subsequently she worked as a talent agent for The Tranum Agency before landing the position of casting director of the soap opera ''Guiding Light''. Rea was the casting director for the Guiding Light from 1970-1996 and concurrently casting director for ''As The World Turns'' from 1979-1983. In 1997 Rea was recognized for her work and inducted into the Soap Opera Hall of Fame. She previously won the Soap Opera Digest Editors Award in 1994 and received the Casting Society of America's Hoyt Bowers Awared in 1995. Rea's many charitable contributions included service as President of the New York Junior League of which she is a lifetime member and on the boards of The Fountain House and The Maternity Center of New York. Rea is survived by two daughters, Edith Rea and Margaret Rea of Los Angeles and a son Peter Rea of Princeton, NJ and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations in Rea's name can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or to the Actors Fund. A memorial service will be held in New York on January 31st at 7 PM, at the Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43 Street.

abstract: PIZZURRO-Margaret Elizabeth Holtkamp, beloved wife of Joseph C. Pizzurro and mother of Joseph, Peter, Virginia, Mary (Esposito), Elizabeth (Ossoff) and Catherine (Hliboki) and grandmother of ten died September 30, 2000 following a short hospitalization. Her two sisters, Sr. Catherine Mary and Esther (Wenzel), and her brother Edward also survive her. Mrs. Pizzurro was born in Kalida, Ohio on December 21, 1924, the second daughter of Edward and Mary Holtkamp. Mrs. Pizzurro attended Mary Manse College of Toledo, Ohio and in 1946 was awarded a B.A. in Chemistry. She earned a M.S. degree from the University of Detroit in Biology in 1948, a notable achievement for a woman at that time. Mrs. Pizzurro is remembered by her friends and family as a woman of unfailing grace and kindness. She was extensively involved in church and charitable activities. She had a lifelong love of music, which she shared through the piano, her singing and work in amateur musicals. Her strength and inner beauty will be cherished by her family and all those whose lives she touched. She was an active parishioner at Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Ardsley for over forty years and most recently attended St. Augustine's parish in Ossining. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 7 to 9PM Monday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Wednesday, Oct. 4 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her name for Alzheimer's disease research to the Mayo Foundation, 200 First Street SW, Rochester, Minnesota 55905.

abstract: SMITH-Philip Cleary, 78, retired Chairman and CEO of the former National Securities and Research Corporation, a New York mutual fund company, died yesterday in Rye, New York from complications following a stroke. A native of Brooklyn, New York, Mr. Smith graduated from Brooklyn Prep, and then attended Williams College before leaving to serve in the US Army during World War II. After the war, he graduated from Fordham University, then Fordham Law School. He joined the New York law firm of Satterlee, Warfield & Stevens and later joined National Securities and Research Corporation from which he retired in 1985. A former resident of Rye, Mr. Smith had moved to Tequesta, Florida where he was a member of Jupiter Hills Country Club. He also maintained a membership in Winged Foot Country Club in Mamaroneck, New York. Mr. Smith was married for 49 years to the former Carol Ann Simonson who died in 1995. He is survived by his five children, Kate McDonnell of Wayne, Pennsylvania, Carol Felch of Sebastopol, California, Cleary Simpson of New Canaan, Connecticut, Lauren Steers of Rye, New York, and Philip C. Smith, Jr. of Charlotte, North Carolina and 11 grandchildren. The family will receive visitors at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, in Rye, New York, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, on Friday November 17th 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye on Saturday, November 18th at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations designated ''for research'' to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 1100, Chicago, IL 60611.

abstract: Ted Graber, an interior decorator popular with affluent West Coast social figures who was chosen by Nancy Reagan to redecorate the family quarters of the White House, died June 3 in Sonoma, Calif. He was 80.     Jean Mathison, his longtime assistant, said the cause was complications from Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Graber retired in 1989 and lived in an assisted living facility in Sonoma.

abstract: GORDON-Lawrence. Born July 26, 1922, died September 8, 2000, of New York and Palm Beach, following a courageous battle with Alzheimer's and cancer. He was the devoted son of the late Harry and Etta Gordon and brother to Seymour. Lawrence is survived by his loving wife Janet and their children, Wendy, Scott, Peter and Petula, and from a previous marriage, daughter Kathy and grandson Eric. A decorated World War II veteran and a pioneer of industry, he was Chairman of the Board and CEO of Lehigh Valley Industries and Blue Ridge Winkler Textiles, among other Fortune 500 companies. Lawrence was a loving, charismatic, brilliant, dynamic, creative and adventurous man, and a champion golfer. Our lives have been blessed by his honor, integrity and love. He was a loving husband, father, colleague and friend, and he will be deeply missed by all who have known him. As Lord Tennyson wrote: ''Love is the only gold.'' Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street, Monday, September 11, 5 PM. A celebration of his life will follow the service. Contributions can be made to: Foundation of Neurologic Diseases, 10 State Street, Newburyport, MA 01950, Attn: Dr. Selkoe or to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Health Care System, First Avenue at 16th St, NY, NY 10003-9973.    GORDON-Lawrence. Co ngregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Lawrence Gordon. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

abstract: GEARHART-Robert Paul, M.D. An attending physician at Lenox Hill Hospital for forty-five years, he died on December 27th, 2000 at the Piedmont Retirement Center in Thomasville, N.C. He was 88 years old. Golda, his wife of 60 years, was at his side. Born in Montoursville, PA., he received a degree in Business Administration from the University of Pittsburgh, before graduating from Temple Medical School in 1939. He interned at Saint Vincent's Hospital in Erie, PA. He then served as Chief Resident at newly opened Triboro Hospital in New York City, before joining the staff at Lenox Hill in 1943. In 1948, he was appointed to the teaching faculty and was named Chief of Pulmonary Medicine in 1964. He served for many years as Chief of the Nursing Health Service and Chief of the Employee Health Service, which were ultimately combined under his direction. With little interest in hospital politics and business, Dr. Gearhart turned down several high-profile opportunities during his career. He much preferred to lead rounds with residents, to brighten the hospital with his spirit and humor, and to dedicate himself to his patients and practice. He retired in 1988. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughter Susan, and her children Shane and Erin; son Robert, Jr. and his daughter Erin; and son Reid. A memorial service will be held January 13 at the Piedmont Retirement Center (336-474-3804). Donations to the Alzheimer's Association or charity of choice.    GEARHART-Robert P., M.D. The Pulmonary Section of Lenox Hill Hospital's Department of Medicine mourns the loss of its former Chief, Dr. Robert Gearhart. A member of the staff since 1943, this gifted and compassionate physician leaves behind a legacy of service to our programs in patient care. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Golda, and his family. Murray R. Rogers, M.D., Chief, Pulmonary Medicine Lenox Hill Hospital

abstract: Researchers meeting in New Orleans report on experiments on brain repair using stem cells derived from recently fertilized eggs, fetuses, the skin on human scalp and the brains of people who have recently died; these cells are grown in a dish and transplanted into damaged animal brains, where they migrate to the site of damage and release factors that ameliorate or may even replace dead tissues; photos (L)
snippet: Researchers meeting in New Orleans report on experiments on brain repair using stem cells derived from recently fertilized eggs, fetuses, the skin on human scalp and the brains of people who have recently died; these cells are grown in a dish and ...
lead_paragraph: Researchers meeting here this week are reporting startling results from experiments to repair damaged brains. They are telling of plucking immature cells out of recently fertilized eggs, fetuses, the skin on a human scalp or -- perhaps even more amazingly -- from the brains of people who had recently died, and growing those cells in a dish. Then they have transplanted the cells back into damaged animal brains.

abstract: Laura Howell Cameron, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald J. Cameron of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Tyler Burns Hale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton H. Hale Jr. of Syracuse. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.    Mrs. Hale, 31, teaches first grade classes at the Nightingale-Bamford School in New York. She graduated from Denison University and received a master's degree in elementary education from Simmons College. Her mother, Alison Cameron, retired as a librarian at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. Her father, an internist, has a private practice in New York and is a clinical associate professor of medicine at Weill Medical College of Cornell University, also in New York.
lead_paragraph: Laura Howell Cameron, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald J. Cameron of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Tyler Burns Hale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton H. lead_paragraph: Here's one of the things you can learn tonight from ''Scientific American Frontiers'': ''Mice living an active and interesting life had more neurons than mice sitting around being bored.'' If you can summon a few neurons of your own, you won't be bored during ''Changing Your Mind,'' the season-opening installment in this earnest series on PBS. As host, Alan Alda again slips effortlessly into the role of curious layman, asking the right questions and nodding affably at the experts' answers.

abstract: Q  I live in a co-op in Carnegie Hill. Our building consists of families, working professionals and retired people. Recently, an apartment was sold to a young couple in their late 20's. Our problem is that now, at all times of the day, morning and night, the odor of marijuana permeates the halls and our elevator, too. We have young children, pregnant women and law-abiding citizens who live in our building, and never has a problem like this occurred. What can be done to stop this? . . . A. Smith, Manhattan    A  Arthur I. Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer who is the vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, said that in most cases, either the proprietary lease, the by-laws or the house rules of a co-op would provide the board of directors with the tools necessary to deal with the problem described by the letter writer.
lead_paragraph: Q I live in a co-op in Carnegie Hill. Our building consists of families, working professionals and retired people. abstract: Philippe Chatrier, former president of International Tennis Federation and French Tennis Federation, dies at age 72; photo (M)
snippet: Philippe Chatrier, former president of International Tennis Federation and French Tennis Federation, dies at age 72; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: There was a time in the 1970's and the 80's, when Philippe Chatrier wore dual chapeaux as president of the International Tennis Federation and president of the French Tennis Federation, that all roads in tennis led through Gaul. That era officially ended Thursday when Mr. Chatrier, the man responsible for the return of tennis to the Olympics and the renaissance of his home Grand Slam tournament, the French Open, as one of the game's four most prestigious championships, died at age 72.
headline.main: Philippe Chatrier, 72, a Force On International Tennis Scene

abstract: Actor Michael J Fox Op-Ed article says outcome of current presidential election could be crucial for medical research; notes opposition by Gov George W Bush and other Republicans in Congress to use of stem cells from aborted fetuses for research on Parkinson's disease and other ailments (M)
snippet: Actor Michael J Fox Op-Ed article says outcome of current presidential election could be crucial for medical research; notes opposition by Gov George W Bush and other Republicans in Congress to use of stem cells from aborted fetuses for research o...
lead_paragraph: As a Parkinson's disease patient and a new American citizen, I look forward to Election Day as something momentous: It's not just the first presidential race in which I can vote (I was born in Canada). The outcome is likely to have a dramatic bearing on my prognosis -- and that of millions of Americans whose lives have been touched by Parkinson's, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal cord injury, Huntington's disease, Alzheimer's disease and other devastating illnesses. That's because one question that may be decided on Tuesday is whether stem cell research -- which holds the best hope of a cure for such diseases -- will be permitted to go forward.

abstract: Seagram Set to Announce An Acquisition by Vivendi  Seagram plans to announce today that it has agreed to be acquired for about $34 billion in stock by Vivendi, the French water utility that is transforming itself into a telecommunications and entertainment giant.    The sale amounts to one of the largest media deals ever and ends the Bronfman family's control over Seagram, which Samuel Bronfman took over in 1928. Vivendi hopes to tap into Seagram's library of films and music and distribute them over its mobile telephone network in France and through its Internet portal and pay-television company. [Page A1.]

abstract: James Bennet article says Democrats dominate cities and Republicans control countryside in recent elections, and suburbanites pick presidents; discusses so-called soccer moms, female suburban swing voters, who this year are up for grabs by either Gov George W Bush or Vice Pres Al Gore; says Bush is younger, warmer personally and far better positioned politically than previous Republican presidential candidates; claims that without strong majority of them, Gore will almost surely lose; notes that Peter Hart, Democratic pollster, regularly calls one suburban Baltimore homemaker, Ruth Cullison, to gauge her feelings about candidates; photo (M)
snippet: James Bennet article says Democrats dominate cities and Republicans control countryside in recent elections, and suburbanites pick presidents; discusses so-called soccer moms, female suburban swing voters, who this year are up for grabs by either ...
lead_paragraph: Chevy Chase is the suburbia where the urbia is the strangest kind of company town -- the company keeps changing. I grew up in a place that few people are from -- most arrive later in life. The rolling hills of Rollingwood are like mountainous divides. Friends and neighbors turn over every four years as the political tides shift. There is a peculiar tension in this pathologically khaki place -- people live in fear of standing out, of being seen. The C.I.A. and F.B.I. go door-to-door collecting information the way the Alzheimer's foundation collects dollars. They ring the bell. ''Are you the lady of the house? We're reviewing the security clearance of one of your neighbors -- we can't tell you which -- and we're wondering if you've noticed anything unusual lately? Anyone coming and going at odd hours, suspicious activity?''

abstract: The Orchid Thief   By Susan Orlean. Ballantine, $14.    The author's first book-length narrative is a journalistic account of a thief caught pilfering 200 rare orchids and plants in Florida, but its true subject is the monomania of collectors and growers, who can wait seven years just to see a new plant bloom. This peculiar mania is revealed as ''a small thing of grandeur, a passion with a pedigree,'' Ted Conover wrote here last year.    The Hours   By Michael Cunningham. Picador USA, $13.    The theme of this Pulitzer Prize-winning novel is the haunting of present lives by memories and books, and it evolves in three connected narratives: that of a New York woman whose life echoes events in Virginia Woolf's ''Mrs. Dalloway''; a housewife in 1940's Los Angeles who reads the book; and Woolf herself in 1923, living near London and writing her novel. ''The overall impression is that of a delicate, triumphant glance, an acknowledgment of Woolf that takes her into Cunningham's own territory, a place of late-century danger but also of treasurable hours,'' Michael Wood wrote in these pages in 1998.    Rocket Boys: A Memoir   By Homer H. Hickam Jr. Delta, $12.95.    This nostalgic coming-of-age story is set during the Sputnik era in dreary West Virginia coal country, where the author (a future NASA engineer) and five pals undertook an audacious series of rocket launchings that captured the imagination of a dying region. ''He is a very adept storyteller,'' James R. Gaines wrote here in 1998.    Bad Chemistry   By Gary Krist. Berkley, $7.50.    A headless body, a combustible dog and ''The Tale of Peter Rabbit'' are among the plot elements in this taut mystery about an ex-policewoman trying to track down her missing husband. ''Fascination with the power of secrets . . . holds the book together,'' David Willis McCullough wrote in these pages in 1998.    Inventing Wyatt Earp: His Life and Many Legends   By Allen Barra. Carroll & Graf, $15.95.    In 1881, a 30-second gunfight helped create an American hero and a stirring myth of frontier justice. It turns out that accounts of Earp's career and the shootout were full of ironies, confusion and outright falsehoods. This ''refreshingly pugnacious book'' aims to set the record straight, Richard E. Nicholls said here last year.    Elegy for Iris   By John Bayley. Picador USA, $13.    The British literary critic chronicles his long, rich relationship with his wife, the novelist Iris Murdoch, and her descent into Alzheimer's disease. ''In its evocation of the lyrical, the comic and the tragic, this splendid book enlarges our imagination of the range and possibilities of love,'' Mary Gordon wrote here in 1998.    There Once Was a World:   A Nine-Hundred-Year Chronicle of the Shtetl of Eishyshok   By Yaffa Eliach. Back Bay/Little, Brown, $25.    A historian recreates in intensely rendered detail the daily rhythms of life in her family's shtetl, a town in what is now Lithuania whose 3,500 Jews were nearly all murdered. Her account contains numerous photographs and interviews with survivors. In 1998 our reviewer, Stephen J. Dubner, called this ''an exhaustive and kaleidoscopic history.'' ''The Rest of Us'': The Rise of America's Eastern European Jews, by Stephen Birmingham (Syracuse University, $22.95), is the final installment in the author's trilogy on Jewish immigrants in America. It is a broad canvas filled with portraits of colorful characters like Irving Berlin, Meyer Lansky and Ralph Lauren. ''Trenchant observations permeate this book,'' Sydney Zion wrote here in 1984.    Face-Time   By Erik Tarloff. Pocket Books, $12.95.    A rising White House speechwriter is horrified when the president takes a shine to his girlfriend. She's flattered, of course, and tempted by the prospect of ultimate insider access. The result is a novel ''about sex and power in Washington that goes behind the headlines to a darker place,'' Patricia O'Brien wrote here last year.    Falling Slowly   By Anita Brookner. Vintage Contemporaries, $12.    This novel focuses on two willfully hermitic sisters torn between a desire for connection with the larger world and a greedy complacency about their carefully sheltered existence. Brookner is ''the unrivaled mistress of the stifled life,'' Claire Messud wrote here last year.    Foreign Bodies   By Hwee Hwee Tan.   Washington Square/Pocket Books, $12.95.    This first novel is about a young lawyer in Singapore who has nine days to prove that her English boyfriend is not the mastermind of an international gambling ring. ''Tan spins out a gripping story,'' Anderson Tepper wrote in the Book Review last year.    Winter Count   By Barry Lopez. Vintage, $11.    Many of these stories focus on obscure figures and incidents in the Plains and Rockies, and are informed by American Indian culture and mystical wisdom. Each tale ''is as economical in design, as painstakingly crafted and as resonant as a good classical guitar,'' David Quammen wrote here in 1981.   Scott Veale

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-9    Victor in Mexico Pledges To Clean Up Legal System  President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada said he would rebuild the country's federal law enforcement system, moving it toward an American model of justice as a way to wipe out the corruption that has crippled Mexico for decades. He also said he would go to the United States soon to meet with President Clinton and both major presidential candidates to press a proposal to open the border to a less-restricted flow of immigrants.   A1

abstract: Dr Allan Zarkin, Beth Israel Medical Center obstetrician, is granted plea bargain that sentences him to five years probation for carving his initials into belly of one of his patients, Dr Liana Gedz, after delivering her child; Zarkin is barred from applying for medical license for five years; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: With the blessing of his victim, a Manhattan obstetrician was granted a plea bargain yesterday that sentences him to five years' probation for carving his initials into the belly of one of his patients after delivering her child. The doctor, Allan Zarkin, 62, will not go to jail, but will be barred from applying for a medical license for five years.

lead_paragraph: THE ANNOUNCEMENT in December that Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. and Monsanto Co. planned to merge and vault into the big leagues of the global pharmaceutical industry landed with a thud on Wall Street. The already-depressed shares of both companies tumbled further, as investors expressed disappointment that the deal, a merger of equals, produced no premium to their share prices. Some Pharmacia owners also criticized the choice of Monsanto, whose genetically altered crops business has raised a storm of consumer protests.
headline.main: The Third Way:Investment Picks From Independent Analysts : Betting on Monsanto And Pharmacia
headline.print_headline: The Third Way:Investment Picks From Independent Analysts : Betting on Monsanto And Pharmacia

abstract: Jane E Brody article on research suggesting that progestin, which many menopausal and postmenopausal women take in combination with estrogen, may be a more important factor than estrogen in development of breast cancers associated with hormone replacement therapy; notes that progestin was included in hormone regimen specifically to prevent estrogen from inducing endometrial cancer, a cancer of urterine lining; says that until issue is settled by studies now under way, a woman should evaluate potential benefits and risks based on her own family and personal medical history, as well as her comfort level with taking or not taking hormones (M)
snippet: Jane E Brody article on research suggesting that progestin, which many menopausal and postmenopausal women take in combination with estrogen, may be a more important factor than estrogen in development of breast cancers associated with hormone rep...
lead_paragraph: ''Should I or shouldn't I?'' It's a question millions of women ask themselves these days, as baby boomers near or recently past menopause try to decide whether to take hormone replacement. Joining them are millions of older women, many of whom have been taking estrogen or a combination of estrogen and progestin for years and wonder if it is wise to continue, as well as many others who wonder if it is wise to start.

lead_paragraph: LAST December, I.B.M. announced a five-year, $100 million program to build the world's most powerful supercomputer. The cascade of impressive figures -- the machine will house a million processors, perform a thousand trillion calculations per second and move a whole Internet's worth of data every second -- hardly raised an eyebrow among supercomputing researchers. What did arouse interest, and a little skepticism, was the announcement that the computer, named Blue Gene, would try to simulate the folding of proteins, a problem that may not be the best match for the new machine's design.
headline.main: WHAT'S NEXT; I.B.M. Plans a Tough Problem for Blue Gene's Million Processors
headline.print_headline: WHAT'S NEXT; I.B.M. Plans a Tough Problem for Blue Gene's Million Processors

abstract: the year in review: search
snippet: the year in review: search
lead_paragraph: WHEN a century turns, nearly everything assumes a ridiculous symbolic weight. What we normally perceive as life as usual suddenly becomes a vision of heaven or hell, of a redeeming future or a yawning abyss. Viewed along these lines, the year 2000 was a sad one for the theater, most notable for losses that signaled the ends of creatively fertile eras. But, if you looked hard, there were heartening signs of new life stirring and a couple of spectacular acts of resurrection.
headline.main: Searching for Happy Chorus Girls and Finding Plays
headline.print_headline: THEATER: YEAR IN REVIEW; Searching for Happy Chorus Girls and Finding Plays

snippet: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on responding to research linking elevated blood levels of amino acid homocysteine to heart attacks and host of other ailments; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Preventive medicine often involves making a best guess based on less than complete scientific information. So it was with smoking, when people were advised to quit long before there was incontrovertible proof that it caused cancer. So it was also with cholesterol, when people were told to lower their blood levels long before research showed that doing so prevented heart attacks.
headline.main: Taking Action Before the Verdict Is In

abstract: THE REFORM PARTY    BUCHANAN RESIGNATION SOUGHT  Reform Party leaders in Colorado and Georgia have called on Pat Buchanan, the leading contender for the Reform presidential nomination, to resign from the party on the grounds that he has been spreading hate and intolerance and ignoring the party procedures. At a meeting last Saturday, the executive committee of the party in Colorado passed a resolution saying that Mr. Buchanan was ''promoting discrimination, intolerance and hatred against various groups of law-abiding American citizens.'' In addition, it condemned remarks attributed to Mr. Buchanan in which homosexuality was called a disorder. ''We just don't have any room for intolerance,'' Victor Good, the party chairman, said. The Reform Party in Georgia called for Mr. Buchanan's resignation after he invited state residents to a May 21 state convention that party leaders said was scheduled illegally. Jim Mangia, secretary of the national Reform Party, predicted that more states would move against Mr. Buchanan. Bay Buchanan, Mr. Buchanan's sister and chief strategist, called the Colorado and Georgia moves ''much ado about nothing.''   Irvin Molotsky (NYT)
lead_paragraph: THE REFORM PARTY
headline.main: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

abstract: Generic drugmaker Mylan Laboratories tentatively agrees to pay $147 million to settle accusations that it improperly cornered market on raw materials for two widely prescribed drugs and then raised price of those drugs, in some instances more than 3,000 percent; if approved, settlement would be largest ever reached by Federal Trade Commission in an anticompetition case and would settle lawsuits filed by the commission, 33 states and variety of other drug purchasers, from large health maintenance organizations to groups of patients; would also break new legal ground by using most of money to reimburse consumers; settlement is also seen as important step in efforts by government to control rapidly rising medical costs; case concerns antianxiety drugs lorazepam, generic version of Ativan, and clorazepate, generic version of Traxene (M)

abstract: Ben Brantley reviews Kenneth Lonergan's play The Waverly Gallery, directed by Scott Ellis; photos (M)
snippet: Ben Brantley reviews Kenneth Lonergan's play The Waverly Gallery, directed by Scott Ellis; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: The elements of what was once an imposing personality glisten like the fragments of a shattered mirror. As a character observes in ''The Waverly Gallery,'' Kenneth Lonergan's stirring and soulful comic drama, it is as if Gladys Green's mind had been ''smashed to pieces.'' You have to look hard to assemble those shards into anything approaching what she was. Look harder, if you dare, and you may see your own future.
