lead_paragraph: Labor Day has come and gone, and I am chagrined to find that I haven't made it through my summer reading. My list comprised only a single book, but a rather unusual one: the text is three billion years old, has six billion copies in print, runs three billion letters long (about one million pages), and is written entirely in four characters (A, T, C, G) with no spaces or punctuation. The book, of course, is a great classic, The Sequence of the Human Genome.

abstract: Andrew Sullivan article rejects the arguments against genetic testing by employers and health insurers, who presumably would discriminate against people on the basis of their DNA; says that while the point of laws against racial bias is to outlaw irrational discrimination based on irrelevant characteristics, barring genetic discrimination would be outlawing rational bias based on relevant information; drawing (L)
snippet: Andrew Sullivan article rejects the arguments against genetic testing by employers and health insurers, who presumably would discriminate against people on the basis of their DNA; says that while the point of laws against racial bias is to outlaw ...
lead_paragraph: When you first think about it, it's a no-brainer. When the final stages of mapping the human genome were hyped last month, both President Bill Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair called for a swift, extensive ban on using genetic information to discriminate in employment or insurance. Clinton had already signed an executive order back in February, banning such discrimination for federal employees. True to form, both politicians had polling data to support them. A 1998 survey of 1,000 randomly selected Americans found that 63 percent of them balked at any genetic testing if an employer or health insurer could have access to the data. So a ban on genetic discrimination not only secures privacy and fairness; it also protects good research by reassuring study volunteers that the information they provide is in completely safe hands.

abstract: Word for Word column excerpts federal appeals court ruling that lower court should not have ordered new trial Texas for death row inmate Calvin Jerold Burdine in 1984 murder of his lover even though his lawyer slept through parts of trial; photo (M)
snippet: Word for Word column excerpts federal appeals court ruling that lower court should not have ordered new trial Texas for death row inmate Calvin Jerold Burdine in 1984 murder of his lover even though his lawyer slept through parts of trial; photo (...
lead_paragraph: In death penalty litigation, all cases are hard. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit -- which, because it includes Texas, is probably the No. 1 circuit in death sentences -- recently heard the case of Calvin Jerold Burdine, who was convicted in 1984 of fatally stabbing his lover. The appeal hinged on an issue that is hard to imagine translating into any other profession. The specific question: At a murder trial where the defense lawyer sleeps, how much sleep is too much?

abstract: Brain-disease model of drug addiction is gaining currency as researchers are able to measure impact of psychoactive substances on neurochemistry of brain with increasing precision, but it is one that is hotly debated; several experts comment; photos (M)
snippet: Brain-disease model of drug addiction is gaining currency as researchers are able to measure impact of psychoactive substances on neurochemistry of brain with increasing precision, but it is one that is hotly debated; several experts comment; phot...
lead_paragraph: Dr. Alan I. Leshner, the director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, a division of the National Institutes of Health, is known for his slide shows. Two or three times a week he gives a speech -- to treatment counselors and prevention specialists, physicians and policymakers -- and almost all feature slides culled from the work of the 1,200 researchers supported by his institute. The slides are of brain scans, and they usually come in pairs. The ''before'' slides show the activity of a normal brain; the ''after'' ones depict a brain that has had prolonged exposure to drugs. Lacing his presentation with jokes and Yiddish expressions -- as a youth, Dr. Leshner summered at a Catskills hotel owned by his grandparents, and he has a bit of Alan King in him -- he tries to translate the science into plain English.
headline.main: Seeing Drugs as a Choice Or as a Brain Anomaly
headline.print_headline: Seeing Drugs as a Choice Or as a Brain Anomaly

abstract: Elie Wiesel article, part of Writers on Writing series, discusses how his study of Judaic sacred literature and love of Yiddish tales influence his work; photo (M)
snippet: Elie Wiesel article, part of Writers on Writing series, discusses how his study of Judaic sacred literature and love of Yiddish tales influence his work; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Most writers speak poorly about their work. And is work the right word? As a child I doubted that telling stories to strangers could be a serious endeavor, especially since often those stories were not even true. Everybody knows that stories are, by definition, the fantasies of those who don't know how to do anything else. I thought of writers as clumsy, lazy and frankly useless. Actually, one could very well live without them.

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-12    Russia Sets Date to End Its Campaign in Chechnya  Lt. Gen. Gennadi Troshev said the Russian military intended to bring the campaign in Chechnya to a close by Feb. 26, which would be a month before presidential elections. The announcement came as Russian forces pressed an assault on Grozny.   A12    Remaking Ulster's Police  Britain said the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the militaristic police force of Northern Ireland, would be reduced in size, have its membership broadened to better reflect the population of the province and have its politically charged name retired. Conservatives in Parliament denounced the decision.   A5

abstract: The booming economy is worsening a severe shortage of the low-wage workers who care for the nation's growing numbers of frail elderly people, health care experts say. abstract: Philip Weiss article on apartment house developer Fred C Trump, who died in 1999; he built Queens foundation for son Donald's Manhattan real-estate empire; photos (M)
snippet: Philip Weiss article on apartment house developer Fred C Trump, who died in 1999; he built Queens foundation for son Donald's Manhattan real-estate empire; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump remembers exactly when he realized his father was beginning to fade. About six years ago, they were driving down Fifth Avenue when he gave his father big news: he had just bought the land beneath the Empire State Building. ''That's a tall building, isn't it?'' Fred C. Trump replied. ''How many apartments are in that building?'' At first, Donald thought he was kidding. But his father, 87, was developing Alzheimer's.

abstract: Aspirin proves to be immensely complicated medication, with unsuspected dimensions to both its powers and its limitations; its benefits for men and women with heart disease remain unchallenged, but it is not clear whether it benefits people who do not have heart disease, and one study has associated a daily aspirin tablet with elevated risk of strokes caused by bleeding into the brain; aspirin also shows promise in preventing dementia, stroke and cancer of digestive tract, a property that may be related to the intestinal problems it sometimes causes; photo (M)
snippet: Aspirin proves to be immensely complicated medication, with unsuspected dimensions to both its powers and its limitations; its benefits for men and women with heart disease remain unchallenged, but it is not clear whether it benefits people who do...
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the story of aspirin is a scientific rags-to-riches fable straight from the pages of Horatio Alger: humble but deserving little pill makes good, transformed after years of plodding fever and headache duty into a powerful, life-saving heart drug.
headline.main: Aspirin: Superhero or Problem Pill?
headline.print_headline: Aspirin: Superhero or Problem Pill?

abstract: First of two articles on Planning for Death describes plight of many old people who are denied their wish for peaceful death without heroic medical measures, even though they had signed 'living wills' outlining that wish; Sabena Wilensky and Rosalind Keyes recall anguish at being unable to stop doctors from putting 91-year-old aunt Bertha Hyman on respirator, because Florida nursing home had not sent her living will or power-of-attorney to hospital; such advance directives often fail because they are lost or forgotten or too vague for relatives or legally-minded hospitals to interpret, or because they are overruled by doctors who refuse to stop treatment; some experts believe very concept is flawed because illness is too unpredictable to be anticipated by simple document; widespread gaps and deficiencies in care of the dying discussed, along with devastating effects on patients and loved ones; photos; maps showing legality of living wills and do-not-resuscitate orders (M)
snippet: First of two articles on Planning for Death describes plight of many old people who are denied their wish for peaceful death without heroic medical measures, even though they had signed 'living wills' outlining that wish; Sabena Wilensky and Rosal...
lead_paragraph: At the age of 91, Bertha Hyman had a clear mind and a firm resolve. When her life neared its end, she wanted no heroic measures: no resuscitation, no respirator, no tangle of tubes. She signed a ''living will'' outlining her wishes, informed two nieces and gave one of them power of attorney to make medical decisions for her if she could no longer make them herself.

abstract: Article on financial problems plaguing Roche Holding focuses on chief exeutive Franz B Humer's plan to revive company's pharmaceutical operations; chart; photo (M)
snippet: Article on financial problems plaguing Roche Holding focuses on chief exeutive Franz B Humer's plan to revive company's pharmaceutical operations; chart; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: MARTIN EBNER has a reputation for pushing the giants of Swiss industry and finance to change their ways and pay more attention to shareholder value. But for Mr. Ebner, a maverick investor who is a kind of Swiss Warren Buffett, Roche Holding was a special case. As recently as 1997, shares in Roche, the pharmaceutical giant based here, accounted for 92 percent of Mr. Ebner's profitable Pharma Vision fund, which rose 24 percent a year, on average, through the 1990's.
headline.main: Roche: Drug Giant Stubbing Its Toes

A salaryman at a trading company that he joined straight out of college, he specialized in arranging financing for the company's activities. abstract: Increasing number of radiologists are advertising and performing new lung cancer screening test done with powerful new spiral CT X-ray scanner, despite uncertainty over whether more people will be harmed than helped by test since scanner's effectiveness has never been rigorously tested; scanner can detect tumor many times small than those found with conventional chest X-ray; Dr Claudia L Henschke, researcher at New York Presbyterian Hospital who pioneered use of scanner, comments; photo (M)
snippet: Increasing number of radiologists are advertising and performing new lung cancer screening test done with powerful new spiral CT X-ray scanner, despite uncertainty over whether more people will be harmed than helped by test since scanner's effecti...
lead_paragraph: When word got out recently that two radiology centers in Portland, Ore., were offering a new screening test for the early detection of lung cancer, the response was overwhelming. Smokers and former smokers jammed the centers' phones, demanding the simple, painless test that can find lung cancers so tiny that they can be snipped out and, doctors hope, the patients cured.

abstract: IT may take the form of toddlers playing a game with an elderly person in a wheelchair. Or it may be able-bodied older people working on literacy skills with children at a clinic. It may be teenagers baking cookies and sharing stories with older residents from their hometown. Or it may be a choir in which the young and the old raise their voices together.    Programs that link different generations have blossomed in Westchester, part of a growing nationwide recognition of the wide-ranging benefits of connecting the young and the old.

abstract: Faltering campaign by some older residents of Shelter Island, NY, to build $750,000 center for island's elderly has been attacked by some of island's old people who think it unnecessary, or fear tax increase, or do not want to appear needy; because nation is aging rapidly, what is happening now in Shelter Island may be harbinger of returning way of life: old there aged there and stayed there; photos; map (M)
snippet: Faltering campaign by some older residents of Shelter Island, NY, to build $750,000 center for island's elderly has been attacked by some of island's old people who think it unnecessary, or fear tax increase, or do not want to appear needy; becaus...
lead_paragraph: Snugly sheltered by geography and sensibility from the workaday bustle of Long Island's North Fork and the antsy glamour of the Hamptons to the south, this summer resort island has become a kind of year-round Elder Dorado. More than a third of its 2,300 winter residents are over 60, twice the average nationally and in the metropolitan area. The percentage may be even higher in summer when the population swells to about 10,000.
headline.main: Hard Choices for a Graying Island; Battle Over Resources May Be Glimpse at America's Future
headline.print_headline: Hard Choices for a Graying Island; Battle Over Resources May Be Glimpse at America's Future

abstract: Special report, Folk Cures on Trial, finds application of rigorous, Western scientific methods to test alternative therapies has become new wave in academic medicine, driven by National Institutes of Health, which, under pressure from Congress, has sharply increased its budget for studies of alternative medicine; institute has established office for alternative medicine, which is gaining acceptance and setting tone for physicians and researchers nationwide; large, multimillion-dollar clinical trials are getting under way at some of nation's most prestigious university hospitals, which, with medical schools, are bowing to economic reality that alternative medicine has become big business; industry surveys find Americans spent $27.2 billion in 1998 on providers of alternative health care, and that 46 percent of American population visited practitioner of alternative medicine in 1997, up from 36 percent in 1990; chart; photo (M)
snippet: Special report, Folk Cures on Trial, finds application of rigorous, Western scientific methods to test alternative therapies has become new wave in academic medicine, driven by National Institutes of Health, which, under pressure from Congress, ha...
lead_paragraph: In the year he has suffered from osteoarthritis, Harold Katcoff has followed his doctors' advice, to no avail: aspirin, steroids, the latest anti-inflammatory drugs. The pills, he says, offer little relief from the stabbing pain in the back of his knees. So Mr. Katcoff, an 80-year-old retired pharmacist, is trying Chinese medicine instead. Or at least, he thinks he is.

abstract: Michael Joseph Gross travel article describes weekend jaunt in Williamstown, Mass; photos; maps (L)0
snippet: Michael Joseph Gross travel article describes weekend jaunt in Williamstown, Mass; photos; maps (L)0
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., in the Purple Valley of the northwestern Berkshires, does all of the stereotypical things that New England towns are supposed to do: it charms, calms and beguiles. Most of all, it nestles. The dramatic peaks of the mountain ranges that surround Williamstown are echoed by the undulating topography of the town itself, and of the Williams College campus at its center. In 1849, Henry David Thoreau famously described the organic relationship of this community to its environment: ''Some will remember, no doubt, not only that they went to the college, but that they went to the mountain. Every visit to its summit would, as it were, generalize the particular information gained below, and subject it to more catholic tests.''
headline.main: Weekend in Williamstown

abstract: By almost anyone's standards, the cholesterol-lowering pill Pravachol is a blockbuster. With $1.7 billion in worldwide sales last year -- $1.1 billion in the United States alone -- the drug is Bristol-Myers Squibb's top-selling product. But it is also a medicine with an inferiority complex.    Pravachol belongs to a class of drugs, statins, that are the most widely prescribed drugs in the United States. Bristol-Myers Squibb, with its pioneering research on the drug, helped create the booming statin market. But a more powerful newcomer, Pfizer's Lipitor, leads the pack in sales.

abstract: Pharmaceutical industry is not developing drugs to treat ailments particular to the third world because it has no incentive to make the huge investment required when the potential customers cannot afford the drugs; industry executives concede the justice in the charge that they would rather develop a cure for a balding American than a dying African; many health policy makers say rich nations may either have to pay manufacturers directly to develop drugs for third-world diseases, offer them tax breaks, dangle before them the carrot of longer patents on their most lucrative drugs, or, in acute crises, simply allow poor countries to declare health emergencies and seize patents to make their own generic versions or buy them from India, Brazil or other countries that ignore Western patent law; problems with the four drugs known to work against sleeping sickness, human African trypanosomiasis, show how the open marketplace that works so well for Americans fails the world's poor; photos (L)

abstract: Article recounts efforts of Pfizer Inc to sell its antibiotic drug Zithromax; using Max, zebra mascot Pfizer devised to help promote drug, Zithromax has rapidly become billion-dollar drug, and has encroached on sales of rival Amoxicillin; last year, after federal officials said that other antibiotics were both cheaper and more successful at treating children's ear infections, Pfizer stepped up its advertising and promotion of Zithromax; Pfizer outspends all other drug manufacturers in consumer advertising; photos; graph (M)
snippet: Article recounts efforts of Pfizer Inc to sell its antibiotic drug Zithromax; using Max, zebra mascot Pfizer devised to help promote drug, Zithromax has rapidly become billion-dollar drug, and has encroached on sales of rival Amoxicillin; last yea...
lead_paragraph: REPLICAS of Max, a small plastic zebra, hang from the stethoscopes of so many pediatricians at the Children's Hospital in Boston that at least one family has asked whether he was the hospital's mascot. But no, Max is a creation of Pfizer Inc., intended to sell an antibiotic called Zithromax. And with Max's help, Zithromax has become a billion-dollar drug in just a few years.

abstract: Melanie Rehak article on poet Anne Carson, whose verse improvisations are being hailed by critics; says her gift for making odd connections, such as pairing Edward Hopper with St Augustine, is one reason Carson has begun attracting serious attention as a poet; holds Carson gives impression of being part of rare group; like her writing, she is both mysterious and magnetic; Carson comments; photos (M)
snippet: Melanie Rehak article on poet Anne Carson, whose verse improvisations are being hailed by critics; says her gift for making odd connections, such as pairing Edward Hopper with St Augustine, is one reason Carson has begun attracting serious attenti...
lead_paragraph: Anne Carson is a poet who likes to get under people's skin. Her new collection, ''Men in the Off Hours,'' features verse in which she variously inhabits the minds (and bodies) of Tolstoy, Lazarus, Freud, Catullus, Sappho and Emily Dickinson. Perhaps her boldest act of channeling, though, comes in a prose poem, ''Irony Is Not Enough: Essay on My Life as Catherine Deneuve,'' which casts the French movie siren in the role of a witty classics professor. (''Sweater buttoned almost to the neck, she sits at the head of the seminar table expounding aspects of Athenian monetary reform.'') Although Carson herself is a classics professor, that's not the connection that led her to write it. ''I saw this movie, 'The Thieves,' about Deneuve being a philosophy teacher in Paris,'' she explains to me. ''In it, she had a sweater just like one of mine. Afterward, I went home and began thinking about what it would be like to be Catherine.''

lead_paragraph: Oct. 1
headline.main: When All the World -- or at Least All the Island -- Is a Stage
headline.print_headline: When All the World -- or at Least All the Island -- Is a Stage

abstract: Al Gore's Journey, 11th in series of articles about lives of presidential candidates, examines Gore's record during his 16 years in Congress, 8 in House and 8 in Senate; from his first days on Capitol Hill, Gore went methodically about task of identifying issues that he could make his own; he was strikingly effective at winning attention by championing just-over-the-horizon consumer-oriented causes such as toxic-waste dumping, genetic testing, global warming; he reveled in mastering arcana of issues average politician might find bloodless or simply too hard, then he tried to popularize issues with voters at large; his strategy was so effective, so media-savvy, that colleagues referred to him as 'Prime Time Al'; Gore's record on Capitol Hill remains vital part of his biography; debate over whether its hallmark was prescience or political expedience will rage over next three months, as he campaigns for presidency; photos (L)
snippet: Al Gore's Journey, 11th in series of articles about lives of presidential candidates, examines Gore's record during his 16 years in Congress, 8 in House and 8 in Senate; from his first days on Capitol Hill, Gore went methodically about task of ide...
lead_paragraph: The Democratic freshman class that was elected to the House of Representatives in 1976 was a remarkable one, loaded with bright and ambitious young reformers who blended the idealism of their generation with the cynicism bred by Watergate and Vietnam. Many would go on to bigger things -- Richard A. Gephardt to the top of the House Democratic leadership, Leon E. Panetta to the White House as chief of staff, Barbara A. Mikulski to the Senate.
